awd_titl_txt: SHF: SMALL: Multiphysics Simulation Algorithms and Experimental Methods for the Development of Cu/Graphene/TMD Hybrid Interconnect Solution
awd_abstract_narration:
As integrated circuits (ICs) have progressed to finer feature sizes and higher levels of integration, interconnect has become a major challenge in IC technology development. Various interconnect solutions developed to date have not yet been able to replace Copper (Cu) interconnects due to their limitations in performance and/or difficulties in fabrication. In this project, novel Copper, Graphene, Transition Metal Dichalcogenide (TMD) hybrid interconnects will be demonstrated and explored by both simulations and experiments, which can compete with Cu nanowires with the same dimensions, and meanwhile have the potential to become the ultimate interconnect solution. The students who participate in this work will be trained with a broad range of skills to sustain future nanotechnology advancement. Education and outreach activities such as inclusive curriculum and culturally relevant teaching, Nano Days in the Birck Nanotechnology Center at Purdue, are also being developed to actively engage women and under-represented minorities into Science and Engineering.

The entire physical process that takes place in a Cu/Graphene/TMD interconnect is yet to be fully understood. The challenge is to understand intricate interactions between multiphysics phenomena involving circuits, electromagnetics, materials, electron transport, and thermal diffusion in a broad band of frequencies. Experimentally, a rapid low-temperature process is critical to preserve the structural integrity of the Cu nanowires during deposition and will be studied. To conquer the aforementioned challenges, multiphysics simulation algorithms and experimental methods will be pursued. On the experimental side, a low temperature chemical vapor deposition recipe, along with a plasma enhanced process, will be developed. Electrical and thermal transport measurements will be performed and correlated with simulations.

por.por_cntn:
Prevailing Cu-based interconnects are reaching their limits in performance and reliability, due to surface and grain boundary scattering at smaller dimensions. It is of critical importance and also highly challenging to develop a new interconnect technology, which can overcome the shortcomings of Cu-interconnects, and have the potential to become the ultimate interconnect solution. In this NSF-funded project, we propose to develop a Cu/Graphene interconnect solution to tackle the challenge of CMOS interconnects. The entire physical process that takes place in a Cu/Graphene interconnect has not been fully understood due to simplified models and simulations. The modeling and simulation is challenging because it involves many physics such as circuits, electromagnetics, materials, electron transport, and thermal diffusion in a broad band of frequencies. Experimentally, a rapid low-temperature process is critical to preserve the structural integrity of the CuNWs during deposition.

In this project, we propose unique multiphysics simulation algorithms and experimental methods to conquer the aforementioned challenges. The multiple physics of the new interconnect are captured rigorously by co-simulating directly in time domain Maxwell?s equations, thermal diffusion equation, equations characterizing Graphene and TMD materials, and Boltzmann equation. Prevailing time-domain methods for solving partial differential equations require a matrix solution. The proposed new algorithm is made naturally free of matrix solutions, and hence has a potential of being orders of magnitude more efficient in time and memory than existing solvers. The challenge of multiple space and hence time scales in the hybrid interconnect are overcome by making the proposed matrix-free time-domain method unconditionally stable. On the experimental side, single-layer molybdenum disulfide (1L MoS2; 0.62 nm) directly grown on SiO2 at 400 ?C is achieved by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD). We also show that this sub-nm barrier can effectively prevent Cu diffusion and tremendously enhance the dielectric reliability. Efforts have also been made to overcome challenges in compatibility, scalability, etc. to introduce new materials to the conventional Cu interconnect technology.  To study the electrical and thermal characteristics of the hybrid wires and Cu diffusion barrier properties of the 2D materials, electrical and thermal transport measurements are performed and correlated with simulations. 

The proposed Cu/Graphene/TMD hybrid technology delivered in the format of multiphysics simulation algorithms and experimental methods provides a feasible solution to the major problems in conventional Cu interconnects. The  novel hybrid interconnects developed in this work have significantly enhanced electrical and thermal performances.. The multiphysics and multiscale simulation capability built in this work, fully validated by measurements, will also serve as a foundation for creating future heterogeneous systems. The students who participate in the proposed work have been trained with a broad range of skills to sustain future nanotechnology advancement.
